seo.title: Trading Glossary – Key Terms & Core Concepts | Qption
seo.description: Clear, concise definitions of essential trading terms: bid/ask, bull & bear markets, volatility, liquidity, support/resistance, trend lines, correlation and more.
seo.keywords: trading glossary, trading terms, bid, ask, bull market, bear market, volatility, liquidity, support, resistance, correlation, trend line, Qption
seo.ogTitle: Trading Glossary – Key Terms & Core Concepts | Qption
seo.ogDescription: Learn the language of the markets with Qption’s glossary: straightforward definitions and examples for key trading concepts.
seo.twitterTitle: Trading Glossary – Key Terms & Core Concepts | Qption
seo.twitterDescription: Essential trading definitions, explained simply for faster learning and better decisions.

terms.title: Ask
terms.desc: The current market price at which you can buy an asset.

terms.title: Bull
terms.desc: A trader or investor who expects prices to rise and buys with the aim of selling later at a higher price.

terms.title: Bull Market
terms.desc: A market environment characterized by broadly rising prices and positive sentiment—often visualized as an upward move on charts.

terms.title: Return
terms.desc: The payout or percentage you receive from a position. On platforms like Qption, traders may receive up to 45% of the investment amount even on a losing trade (as configured per asset). The return rate is set at purchase.

terms.title: Volatility
terms.desc: The degree of price fluctuation over a given period. Higher volatility means larger, faster price swings.

terms.title: Deposit
terms.desc: Funds available in a trading account that can be used to open and manage positions.

terms.title: Diversification
terms.desc: A risk-management approach of spreading capital across different assets or markets to reduce exposure to any single position.

terms.title: Indicator
terms.desc: A technical analysis tool derived from price/volume data, used to assess trend, momentum or volatility and inform trading decisions.

terms.title: Bid
terms.desc: The current market price at which you can sell an asset.

terms.title: Price Corridor
terms.desc: A price range on the chart bounded by support (lower boundary) and resistance (upper boundary) within which the asset trades.

terms.title: Correction
terms.desc: A temporary counter-trend move that retraces part of a strong advance or decline before the prior trend potentially resumes.

terms.title: Correlation
terms.desc: A measure of how two assets move relative to each other, from −1 (inverse) to +1 (direct). Example: EUR/USD and GBP/USD often move in similar directions.

terms.title: Liquidity
terms.desc: How easily an asset can be bought or sold without materially moving its price. Higher trading volume typically implies greater liquidity.

terms.title: Support Line
terms.desc: A price area where buying interest historically emerges and helps prevent further declines.

terms.title: Resistance Line
terms.desc: A price area where selling interest historically emerges and helps limit further advances.

terms.title: Trend Line
terms.desc: A line connecting successive higher lows in an uptrend (support) or lower highs in a downtrend (resistance) to illustrate trend direction.

terms.title: Bear
terms.desc: A trader or investor who expects prices to fall and looks to profit from declines.

terms.title: Bear Market
terms.desc: A prolonged period of broadly falling prices and negative sentiment—often depicted as persistent downtrends on charts.

terms.title: Bear Raid
terms.desc: A coordinated effort by traders to push an asset’s price lower, typically via concentrated selling.

terms.title: Trader Sentiment
terms.desc: An indicator reflecting the overall bias of market participants (e.g., the proportion of long vs. short positions).

terms.title: Bar
terms.desc: A chart element that displays open, high, low and close (OHLC) for a specific time period; used in bar charts.

terms.title: Bonus
terms.desc: Extra funds credited by the platform (e.g., as a promotion or deposit incentive) that can be used for trading under specific terms.
